narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study?
comments: I think for the most part, instructor identified topic of study pretty clearly.

narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework?
comments: I think too much time and effort was put into what is essentially "tech design", when more overarching production planning themes and concepts could have been discussed instead.
the expectations from the homework were not very clearly defined when the assignment was introduced, but discussions and reviews with the instructor made it clearer later on.

I feel like many of the things that were graded off on the projects were not explained as expectations prior to the deadline. It was also very hard to learn from mistakes we made on the first project when they were handed back after the first assignment.

narratives.question_text: How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented?
comments: Sometimes lectures went off on tangents.
more time should be put in for question answer sessions and more case studies.

narratives.question_text: How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course?
comments: very helpful. especially for start ups.

I think the work was incredibly geared towards students with technical theater experience. I imagine the class would have been exponentially harder without some requisite technical knowledge, especially of scenery production.

narratives.question_text: How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom?
comments: I personally did not reach out to the instructor except for once but he seemed to be available if we made appointment ahead of time.

narratives.question_text: How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic?
comments: Success on the assignments was far more based on your technical design experience than it was on your understanding of the course material.

narratives.question_text: If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
comments: Tests should measure your understanding of the material, rather than your memorization and rote regurgitation. Any question that begins along the lines of "List 15 of the 17 items..." is NOT testing your understanding of the concepts of the course - just how much you studied the evening prior. I don't know what the correct kind of assessment is for the material, but this wasn't it.
Tests simply require rote memorization of the lectures.
discussions with instructor helped to understand the process better.

narratives.question_text: How useful was this course in preparing you for production work?
comments: it helps with understanding one's role in the planning process. also, helps to understand the planning process we have used previously and its pros and cons.
This class was very good at informing me of how production work is run at Yale and why it is done that way. I am not sure I learned too much new about how production is run outside of Yale.

narratives.question_text: How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
comments: I think it would be great if he has outline of the lecture for the day printed or distributed in some way so we can follow better.

I think it is not acceptable to grade people based on the work of others, outside their control. Group projects where the group shares one grade are absolutely unfair when one person ends up carrying the majority of the weight, just to ensure they can do well. Allow the projects to be broken up into pieces and grade based on who did which pieces.

I think this class has invaluable information for being a production or technical manager. However the course suffers from dated content and dogmatic support of certain management prescriptions. Thinking abstractly about managing a production is a very useful exercise, but this class is not a conducive environment to critical discussion. There are certainly good reasons behind "the way we do thing at YSD", but this course often seems limited by the impulse to dismiss any other way of doing things as inferior.
more case studies. student presentations ?
